TITLE: CCU Progress Note
   - PCI of the RCA
   - Intubated, overbreathing vent
   - Acidotic, improved overnight so weaning FiO2
   - Increasing hypotension initially
   - Started on dopamine at cath. Increased up to 15ug/kg/min for
   hypotension. Weaned somewhat with fluids + dobutamine so ultimately at
   dopamine 8ug/kg/min + dobutamine 5ug/kg/min
   - Given 4L fluids overnight
   - Low UOP around 30mL/hour up to 70mL/hour with boluses
   - Persistently hypothermic
   - A-line placed
   Allergies:
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Dopamine - 8 mcg/Kg/min
   Fentanyl - 25 mcg/hour
   Midazolam (Versed) - 2 mg/hour
   Dobutamine - 5 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2166-2-13**] 05:55 AM
   Vital signs
   Hemodynamic monitoring
   Fluid balance

                                                               Since 12 AM

    CVP: 7 (7 - 12)mmHg

   Vt (Set): 550 (550 - 550) mL
   RR (Set): 22
   PEEP: 5 cmH2O
   FiO2: 50%
   RSBI Deferred: Hemodynamic Instability
   PIP: 24 cmH2O
   Plateau: 16 cmH2O
   SpO2: 95%
   ABG: 7.35/39/170/25/-3
   Ve: 13.5 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 340
   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: Elderly man. Intubated.  Arousable. Wearing bair hugger.
   HEENT: Right eye constricts to light, surgical left pupil. MM dry.
   Intubated.
   NECK: IJ (from OSH) left side, bandage on right side, unable to assess
   JVP.
   CARDIAC: No murmurs, difficult to ascultate over mechanical BS.
   LUNGS: Cachectic.  Mechanical clear breath sounds.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. + BS
   EXTREMITIES: No edema. distal pulses present.  A-line in the L radial
   artery
   NEURO: Opens eyes, nods on commands. Withdraws to pain.

                             [**2166-2-12**]  07:43 PM
                             [**2166-2-12**]  08:21 PM
                             [**2166-2-12**]  11:26 PM
                             [**2166-2-13**]  01:02 AM
   WBC
   11.3
   Hct
   30.5
   28.0
   Plt
   366
   Cr
   1.4
   TropT
   0.23
   TCO2
   24
   22
   Glucose
   123
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:21.3/38.5/2.0, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:/44/0.23, ALT / AST:42/53, Alk Phos / T Bili:139/,
   Differential-Neuts:94.7 %, Lymph:3.6 %, Mono:1.2 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.2 mmol/L, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:5.4 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA 325mg PO daily, Plavix 75mg PO daily
   -hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel pending
   - HbA1c pending
   -CEs in am
   # PUMP:  EF unknown. No elevated filling pressures on right heart
   cath.
   -TTE pending
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am pending
   # Hypotension - requiring dopamine post cath, likely in setting of RV
   infarct.  Also may have been try prior to procedure as was found down
   after an undefined period of time prior to OSH admission with ARF.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.
   -stat HCT unchanged (30 on admission, 28 on repeat after several liters
   of fluids)
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Ddx includes early renal failure vs
   possible aggressive IVF with NS.  No evidence GI losses.
   -Switch to LR for hydration.
   -monitor renal function
   -serial ABGs
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. On bair hugger. In setting of
   hypotension and leukocytosis (although both can likely be explained by
   MI), will be wary of developing sepsis. TSH WNL.  Also possible in
   setting of malnutrition (pt appears cachectic, albumin is low), or may
   be inaccurate temp in setting of cardiogenic shock.
   -CBCd in am
   -Blood and urine cx, UA bland at OSH.
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate tomorrow, initiate TF.
   Agressive IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now, contact, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 322**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3872**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2166-2-12**] 07:35 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2166-2-12**] 08:58 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2166-2-13**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with inferior STEMI and underwent PCI of the RCA. He was intubated and placed on a ventilator due to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing hypotension, requiring dopamine and dobutamine to maintain blood pressure. He has also been experiencing acidosis, which has improved overnight. His temperature is persistently hypothermic, and he has a low urine output.

Assessment:

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac: Inferior STEMI, RV infarct, and hypotension requiring pressors.
2. Respiratory: Respiratory failure, intubated and on a ventilator, mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
3. Renal: Acute kidney injury, unclear baseline, and possible early renal failure.
4. Metabolic: Metabolic acidosis, non-anion gap, and possible aggressive IVF with NS.
5. Hypothermia: Persistently hypothermic, unclear etiology.
6. Leukocytosis: Elevated white blood cell count, unclear etiology.

Plan:

1. Cardiac: Continue to monitor and manage hypotension with pressors, consider PA catheter for improved monitoring.
2. Respiratory: Wean FiO2 as tolerated, increase RR, and titrate down PEEP if tolerated.
3. Renal: Monitor renal function, serial ABGs, and consider mucomyst and bicarb for acidosis.
4. Metabolic: Monitor metabolic acidosis, consider switching to LR for hydration, and monitor renal function.
5. Hypothermia: Monitor temperature, consider CBCd in am, and discuss with family/prior PCP.
6. Leukocytosis: Monitor white blood cell count, consider CBCd in am, and discuss with family/prior PCP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's hypotension, leukocytosis, and hypothermia, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to renal failure.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's inferior STEMI and RV infarct may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
5. Metabolic Complications: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to metabolic complications, such as lactic acidosis or hyperkalemia.
6. Hypothermia: The patient's persistently hypothermic temperature may worsen, leading to hypothermic complications, such as cardiac arrest or respiratory failure.

   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR

   .

   .

   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man who underwent PCI for an inferior STEMI and is currently in the ICU. He is intubated and on ventilator support with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. He has been experiencing hypotension, which has been treated with dopamine and dobutamine. His CVP is low, and his right-sided filling pressures are normal despite large volume resuscitation. He has a history of a large infero-posterior MI and is suspected to have RV infarction. His lab results show elevated troponin and CK levels, and he has a low hemoglobin level. He is also hypothermic and has a low urine output.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Cardiac tamponade
	* Cardiac rupture
	* Ventricular fibrillation
	* Cardiac arrest
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia
	* Respiratory failure
	* Pneumothorax
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
4. Metabolic complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis
	* Hypoglycemia
	* Hyperglycemia
5. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis
	* SIRS
	* Pneumonia
6. Other complications:
	* Hypothermia
	* Hypovolemic shock
	* Cardiogenic shock

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Wean dopamine and dobutamine as tolerated and consider switching to alternative inotropes.
3. Continue to provide aggressive IVF to maintain preload augmentation.
4. Monitor the patient's urine output and consider increasing fluid administration if necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and consider warming measures if necessary.
6. Consider repeating ABG and adjusting ventilator settings as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and consider adjusting treatment accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's lab results and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Consider repeating cardiac enzymes and troponin levels to monitor for signs of cardiac injury.
10. Continue to provide supportive care, including pain management and sedation, as necessary.

   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic, on dopamine and dobutamine.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis,
   since hypothermic to 95, cultures and imaging thus far negative.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   have some contribution from positive pressure ventilation as well.
   - Monitor culture results
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.

   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who underwent RCA revascularization and is currently in the ICU. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has been experiencing hypotension, which has been treated with dopamine and dobutamine. The patient has also been experiencing acidosis, which has been improved with fluid therapy.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 104 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 87/47 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 11.3 K/uL
* Platelet count: 366 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.23 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.4 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Dopamine: 8 mcg/kg/min
* Dobutamine: 5 mcg/kg/min
* Fentanyl: 25 mcg/hour
* Midazolam (Versed): 2 mg/hour
* Aspirin: 81 mg/day
* Plavix: 75 mg/day
* Statin: high-dose

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Hold beta blockers until off pressors
* Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IV fluids for preload augmentation
* Monitor for signs of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, and changes in mental status
* Continue to monitor for signs of RV dysfunction, including decreased cardiac output and increased CVP
* Repeat ABG and adjust PEEP as tolerated
* Continue to monitor for signs of metabolic acidosis, including increased lactate levels and decreased pH
* Monitor for signs of hypothermia, including decreased temperature and increased WBC count
* Consider placement of a PA catheter for improved monitoring of cardiac function
* Consider placement of a Swan-Ganz catheter for improved monitoring of cardiac function
* Continue to monitor for signs of respiratory failure, including decreased oxygen saturation and increased respiratory rate

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: due to the patient's hypothermia and positive blood cultures
* RV dysfunction: due to the patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output
* Metabolic acidosis: due to the patient's lactic acidosis and decreased pH
* Hypothermia: due to the patient's low body temperature and decreased WBC count
* Respiratory failure: due to the patient's decreased oxygen saturation and increased respiratory rate
* Cardiac arrest: due to the patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output

Overall, the patient's condition is unstable and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU following an inferior STEMI and subsequent RCA revascularization. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and is dependent on pressors to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's acidosis has improved overnight, and his FiO2 is being weaned. He is receiving dopamine and dobutamine to support his blood pressure, and has been given 4L of fluids overnight. His urine output is low, but has increased to 70mL/hour with the use of boluses.

The patient is persistently hypothermic, and his temperature is currently 37.1C. He has a central line in place, and an arterial line in his left radial artery.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating ongoing cardiac injury. His creatinine has increased to 1.4mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is elevated. His white blood cell count is 11.3K/L, and his platelet count is 366K/L.

The patient's plan of care includes holding beta blockers until he is off pressors, weaning pressors as tolerated, and favoring aggressive IV fluids for preload augmentation. He will also receive high-dose statins, and lipid panels and HbA1C will be obtained for risk stratification.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's dependence on pressors to maintain blood pressure suggests that he may be at risk for cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypothermia and low white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels suggest that he may be at risk for acute kidney injury.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing need for mechanical ventilation and his mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ongoing metabolic acidosis may require ongoing treatment with bicarbonate and other interventions.
6. Hypothermia: The patient's persistent hypothermia may require ongoing treatment with warming measures.
7. Pulmonary edema: The patient's ongoing need for pressors and his elevated troponin levels suggest that he may be at risk for pulmonary edema.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing close monitoring and treatment to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a complex medical history. The patient has undergone several interventions, including RIJ and LIJ placement, PPD placement, and infusion of various medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and is receiving Dobutamine and Dopamine infusions.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of cardiac injury, with elevated troponin-T levels and ST-segment elevation on the ECG. The patient also has evidence of respiratory failure, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 270 and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the presence of multiple lines and tubes, but the patient is able to respond to verbal commands and has no evidence of neurological deficits.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of myocardial infarction and the presence of Dobutamine and Dopamine infusions, there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is low, indicating a risk of respiratory failure. Weaning the patient off the ventilator may be challenging.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and presence of a pulmonary nodule may indicate a risk of sepsis.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is low, and the presence of multiple lines and tubes may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and there is a risk of hypotension worsening if not managed properly.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex ICU admission with multiple medical issues. Close monitoring and management of the patient's condition is essential to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of pulmonary nodule, myocardial infarction, and hypotension. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40%. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. He is receiving Dobutamine, Dopamine, and Midazolam infusions. His laboratory results show an elevated troponin-T level, indicating ongoing myocardial injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of myocardial infarction and ongoing myocardial injury increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is fragile, and the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is high. The use of high-pressure ventilation and the presence of a pulmonary nodule may increase the risk of respiratory complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of pulmonary nodule and myocardial infarction may increase the risk of sepsis, particularly if the pulmonary nodule is infected.
4. Renal complications: The patient's elevated troponin-T level and history of myocardial infarction may increase the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of hypotension and hypothermia may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and ulceration.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of hypotension and hypothermia may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
7. Infection: The patient's history of pulmonary nodule and myocardial infarction may increase the risk of infection, particularly if the pulmonary nodule is infected.
8. Thrombotic complications: The patient's history of hypotension and hypothermia may increase the risk of thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to identify potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel and HbA1C for risk stratification
   .
   # PUMP:  Responding to IV fluids suggesting RV dysfunction possibly
   related to ischemic territory, however, CVP is low.  EF unknown. No
   elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE today
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic, on dopamine and dobutamine.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis,
   since hypothermic to 95, cultures and imaging thus far negative.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   have some contribution from positive pressure ventilation as well.
   - Monitor culture results
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 80-year-old man with limited known medical history who presented with inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization.
* He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40%.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg.
* He has a low central venous pressure (CVP) of 7 mmHg and is receiving dopamine and dobutamine infusions to support his blood pressure.
* His laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 23 mmol/L.
* He has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and his lactate level is elevated at 0.9 mmol/L.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's mechanical ventilation and FiO2 of 40% may lead to respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory failure.
* Renal complications: The patient's AKI and elevated BUN level may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further kidney damage and potentially requiring dialysis.
* Sepsis: The patient's low CVP and elevated lactate level suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis, which could be exacerbated by his mechanical ventilation and pressor support.
* Metabolic complications: The patient's mixed acidosis and elevated lactate level may lead to further metabolic complications such as electrolyte imbalances and hypoglycemia if not managed properly.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status.
* Wean the patient off pressors and consider introducing vasopressin if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's CVP and consider inserting a pulmonary artery catheter if it remains low.
* Continue to provide aggressive IV fluids to support the patient's blood pressure and renal function.
* Consider initiating a stress ulcer prophylaxis and DVT prophylaxis.
* Monitor the patient's temperature and consider initiating antipyretics if necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider initiating a psychological evaluation if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and is currently intubated. He has been on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and is receiving dopamine and dobutamine infusions for hemodynamic support. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 17 inspirations per minute and a tidal volume of 550 mL.

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, and his cardiac status is being monitored closely. He has been prescribed ASA, Plavix, and a high-dose statin, and is being weaned off pressors.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL. He is receiving IV fluids and diuretics to manage his fluid status and urine output.

The patient's respiratory status is also being monitored closely, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis noted on his ABG. His lung function is being assessed, and he is receiving oxygen therapy as needed.

The patient's temperature is stable, with a current temperature of 36.3C. His WBC count is elevated, and he has a history of hypothermia.

The patient's electrolyte levels are being monitored closely, and he is receiving IV fluids and electrolyte replacement as needed.

The patient's social situation is concerning, with reports of him being found down and his household being described as unkept. His safety at home is unclear, and social work and physical therapy services have been initiated.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is being closely monitored, and he is at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and he is at risk for respiratory complications such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Renal complications: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he is at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's immunocompromised state and history of hypothermia make him at risk for infectious complications such as sepsis, pneumonia, and wound infections.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's metabolic acidosis and impaired renal function make him at risk for metabolic complications such as hyperkalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of hypothermia and impaired cardiac function make him at risk for neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of hypothermia and impaired cardiac function make him at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, and small intestine obstruction.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   - Pt. should not need ionotropic support, therefore will wean
   dobutamine and titrate up dopamine prn
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at OSH.
    No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and
   metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy
   - ruling out for TB, [**1-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm)
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.  IVF boluses prn as
   above.  Lytes prn.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40%. He is receiving Dobutamine and Dopamine infusions for hemodynamic support.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and his SpO2 is 96%. His CVP is 7 mmHg, and his MAP is 50s.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he is receiving pressor support. The etiology of his hypotension is unclear, but it is likely related to sepsis, cardiogenic shock, or hypovolemia.
2. ARF: The patient's creatinine has increased from 1.1 mg/dL at OSH to 1.4 mg/dL in the ICU. He is receiving IVF boluses to improve his CVP and MAP.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which is likely related to his underlying medical condition.
4. Sepsis: The patient has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be related to sepsis.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's acid-base status is abnormal, with a pH of 7.38 and a bicarbonate level of 24 mmol/L.

The patient's labs are significant for:

* WBC count: 9.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 264 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 125 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.66 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L

The patient's plan includes:

1. Weaning of Dobutamine and titration of Dopamine to maintain a MAP of 60 mmHg.
2. IVF boluses to improve CVP and MAP.
3. Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells.
4. Monitoring of culture results and temperature curve.
5. Trial of PS to wean sedation and potentially extubate the patient.
6. Consultation with IP for possible transbronchial biopsy to rule out TB.
7. PPD placement on the patient's left forearm to rule out TB.
8. Negative pressure room isolation to reduce the risk of transmission of TB.
9. Nutrition consult for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and IVF boluses.
10. Monitoring of the patient's acid-base status and electrolyte levels.

The patient's disposition is currently in the ICU, and he will be discussed with his family today regarding his further care.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male who presented from the operating room (OSH) with an inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization. He is currently intubated and dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 74 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg. His respiratory status is also stable, with a FiO2 of 40% and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. His laboratory results show mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE, with an EF of 45-50%. His WBC count is 9.3 K/uL, and his troponin-T level is 0.66.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient's temperature is slightly elevated, and he has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which may indicate an infectious process.
2. ARF: The patient's creatinine level has increased from 1.1 mg/dL at OSH to 1.4 mg/dL, and he has a metabolic acidosis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
4. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature was 94.7C on admission, and he is at risk for sepsis.
5. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's systolic function is preserved on TTE, but he is still dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning of dopamine and dobutamine and titration of dopamine.
2. Holding beta blockers until the patient is off pressors.
3. Aggressive IV fluid administration for preload augmentation.
4. Monitoring of culture results and temperature curve.
5. Repeat ABG and decreasing PEEP if tolerated.
6. Consideration of PA catheter placement for improved monitoring.
7. Monitoring of respiratory status and adjusting FiO2 as tolerated.
8. Consideration of steroid studies.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to the CCU for now.

   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc

   admission.  Now improved

   .

   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with an inferior STEMI and was subsequently intubated and transferred to the ICU. He has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone revascularization. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.3C, HR 74 bpm, BP 99/46 mmHg, RR 17 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 7 mmHg, MAP 50s, DO2 11.9 L/min
* Respiratory support: Mechanical ventilation, FiO2 40%, PEEP 5 cmH2O
* Laboratory results: WBC 9.3 K/uL, Hct 28.0%, Plt 264 K/uL, Cr 1.2 mg/dL, TropT 0.66 ng/mL
* Medical history: Coronary artery disease, revascularization, hypertension, hyperlipidemia
* Current medications: Dobutamine, dopamine, midazolam, fentanyl, pantoprazole, heparin

Potential medical complications:

* Hypovolemic shock: The patient's CVP is low, and he is receiving IV fluids to improve his hypovolemic status.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function.
* Cardiac failure: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone revascularization, but his cardiac function is currently unknown.
* Sepsis: The patient's temperature is low, and he has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be indicative of an infectious process.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may be related to his respiratory failure and underlying medical conditions.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is receiving IV fluids to improve his renal function.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy, and there is a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Assessment and plan:

* The patient's hypovolemic status will be monitored and treated with IV fluids as needed.
* The patient's respiratory function will be closely monitored, and he will be weaned from mechanical ventilation as tolerated.
* The patient's cardiac function will be monitored, and he will receive treatment for any cardiac complications that arise.
* The patient's sepsis will be monitored and treated with antibiotics as needed.
* The patient's metabolic acidosis will be monitored and treated with IV fluids and other supportive measures as needed.
* The patient's renal function will be monitored, and he will receive treatment for any renal complications that arise.
* The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk will be monitored, and he will receive treatment for any bleeding that occurs.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of RCA infarct. He underwent RCA revascularization and is currently being treated for hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be indicative of an infectious process. His temperature has been fluctuating, and his WBC count is elevated.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is dependent on dopamine and norepinephrine to maintain his blood pressure. He has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE, and his EF is 45-50%.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient is intubated and has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. He may require weaning from sedation and pressors, and possible extubation trial.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels have increased, and he has low urine output. He may require further fluid resuscitation and diuretic therapy.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may be due to his underlying conditions.
6. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature has been fluctuating, and he may be at risk for hypothermia.
7. Lung/liver mass: The patient has a cavitary lesion in his right lung apex and a lesion in his liver, which may be indicative of a malignant or infectious process.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Monitoring culture results and checking for sepsis.
2. Weaning pressors and sedation as tolerated.
3. Continuing IVF boluses and RBC transfusions as needed.
4. Ruling out adrenal insufficiency with a free cortisol test.
5. Discussing further PMH with family today when they arrive.
6. SW and PT when able.
7. NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve his clinical status.

   Mg++:2.5 mg/dL, PO4:2.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   - Pt. should not need ionotropic support, therefore will wean
   dobutamine and titrate up dopamine prn
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy
   - ruling out for TB, [**1-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm)
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.  IVF boluses prn as
   above.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ removed, RIJ placed [**2-13**],  A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with inferior STEMI, was treated with RCA revascularization, and is currently in the ICU due to cardiogenic shock.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36C, heart rate of 53 bpm, and blood pressure of 154/77 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 94% on FiO2 50%. His respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation, and his ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

The patient has a history of RCA infarct, and his cardiac function is compromised, with an EF of 45-50% on TTE. He is dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support and is being weaned off pressors. His CVP is low, and his RV function appears normal on TTE.

The patient has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which is concerning for TB or malignancy. He has also had a positive pressure room and negative pressure room, and his sputum samples have been sent for TB testing.

The patient has a history of hypovolemia, and his creatinine level has improved to 1.2 after hydration. He is being monitored for ARF, and his electrolytes are being managed prn.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying cardiopulmonary disease, and he is being weaned off sedation and trial PS. He is also being considered for extubation today or tomorrow pending a decision regarding a possible lung biopsy.

The patient has a history of metabolic acidosis, which has resolved with fluids. He is being monitored for hypothermia, and his temperature is stable.

The patient's psychosocial situation is concerning, as he was found down and his household is described as unkempt. He is being referred to social work and physical therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support. He is at risk for cardiac arrest, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying cardiopulmonary disease, and he is at risk for respiratory failure, respiratory arrest, and pulmonary embolism.
3. Infectious complications: The patient has a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex and a lesion in the liver, which is concerning for TB or malignancy. He is at risk for sepsis, pneumonia, and other infectious complications.
4. Renal complications: The patient has a history of ARF, and his creatinine level has improved to 1.2 after hydration. He is at risk for further kidney damage and chronic kidney disease.
5. Neurological complications: The patient is sedated and has a history of hypovolemia, which can lead to neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, and cerebral edema.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of hypovolemia and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, ileus, and other gastrointestinal complications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a RCA infarct and has been undergoing treatment for cardiogenic shock, sepsis, and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is summarized as follows:

* Cardiovascular: The patient is currently on norepinephrine to support blood pressure, which has been labile. The patient has a preserved systolic function on TTE and no evidence of pulmonary embolism on CXR. The differential diagnosis for hypotension includes cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and hypovolemic shock.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on assist control ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%. The patient's ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. The patient is not hypoventilated based on their ABG.
* Coronaries: The patient had a total occlusion of the RCA, which was treated with BMS. The patient is dopamine/dobutamine dependent post-catheterization and has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE.
* PUMP: The patient's initial concern for RV dysfunction has been ruled out, and the patient's CVP is low. The patient's TTE shows an EF of 45-50%.
* RHYTHM: The patient's rhythm is currently normal sinus rhythm, but they were increasingly tachycardic on the evening of admission.
* ARF: The patient's creatinine has improved to 1.1 today after hydration, suggesting that the patient's ARF is likely due to hypovolemia.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis has resolved with fluids.
* Hypothermia: The patient's temperature was 94.7 on admission, and the patient's culture data is being monitored for sepsis.
* Lung/liver mass: The patient has a RUL cavitary lesion on CT and a lesion in the liver, which is concerning for TB or malignancy.
* Psychosocial: The patient's household is described as unkept, and it is unclear if the patient is safe alone at home.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to cardiogenic shock.
* Sepsis: The patient's culture data is pending, and the patient's temperature curve and WBC curve are being monitored for signs of sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further acidosis and hypoxia.
* ARF: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Hypothermia: The patient's hypothermia may worsen, leading to further complications.
* Lung/liver mass: The patient's lung/liver mass may be malignant or tubercular, leading to further complications.
* Psychosocial: The patient's psychosocial situation may worsen, leading to further complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring culture results
* Continuing IVF boluses
* Weaning pressors as tolerated
* Checking free cortisol levels
* Attempting to wean sedation and possibly extubate the patient
* Holding BB until off pressors
* Weaning pressors as tolerated
* Continuing high-dose statin
* Ruling out TB for the lung/liver mass
* Discussing further PMH with family today
* Providing SW and PT services as needed.

   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   - Pt. should not need ionotropic support, therefore will wean
   dobutamine and titrate up dopamine prn
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on
   exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
   - transfuse 2 units pRBCs
   - Cont. pressors, wean dobutamine and titrate up dopamine as needed for
   goal MAP >60
   - a-line
   - if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.2 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  No known h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis.
   - wean sedation
   - Trial PS today
   - Currently not protecting airway given [**Month (only) 202**]. gag, will follow with
   weaning sedation
   - If MS improves will attempt extubation today vs tomorrow pending
   decision regarding possible lung biopsy
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   - consult IP for possible transbronchial biopsy
   - ruling out for TB, [**1-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm)
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of RCA infarct, s/p RCA revascularization, and mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE. The patient has been on dopamine and dobutamine for cardiac support, and his blood pressure has been labile.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36C (96.8F)
* Heart rate: 53 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 154/77 mmHg (104/50-235/77 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 7 mmHg

The patient has been receiving various medications, including norepinephrine, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 9.6 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.3 g/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 22 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+ 141 mEq/L, K+ 4.5 mEq/L, Cl- 103 mEq/L
* Glucose: 116 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.66 ng/mL
* Creatine kinase (CK): 592 IU/L
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: no evidence of pneumothorax (PTX)
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: RUL cavitary lesion and lesion in the liver

The patient's medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock
	* Ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation
	* Cardiac arrest
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
	* Respiratory failure
3. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis
	* Bacterial pneumonia
	* Tuberculosis (TB)
4. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
5. Metabolic complications:
	* Hyperglycemia
	* Hypoglycemia
6. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Stress ulcer bleeding
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding
7. Neurological complications:
	* Seizures
	* Stroke
8. Hematological complications:
	* Anemia
	* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's ongoing care plan includes:

* Weaning sedation and pressors as tolerated
* Continuing IVF boluses for CVP goal >15
* Transfusing 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs)
* Monitoring culture results
* Considering a lung biopsy to rule out TB
* Consulting with infectious disease and pulmonary medicine specialists
* Continuing stress ulcer prophylaxis and bowel regimen
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting therapy accordingly.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p

   .
   # Hypotension
 Pt s/p inferior STEMI, initially hypotensive requiring
   dopamine/dobutamine. Switched to levo.  Turned off yesterday am, pt
   extubated, later on became bradycardic and hypotensive. Was on levophed
   with labile BPs, now back on dopamine, and IVF for hypotensive.  Ddx
   for this new episode:  Less likely primarily cardiac as no evidence of
   ECG changes, increase in CEs, possibly in setting of vagal episode or
   aspiration.  Also on ddx is primary neurologic process, acute stroke,
   metastatic disease or anoxic brain injury.
   - Dopamine prn and IVF boluses for BP, needs new a-line today.
   - F/u cx, covering broadly with vanc/zosyn for asp pna, needs ID
   approval today, planned 8 day course.  Started evening of [**2-15**].
   - CT followed by MRI to eval above neuro issues, ? neuro c/s.
   .
   # Respiratory failure - intubated in setting of code at OSH.  No known
   h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing one
   exam.  The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] is
   hypoventilating [**2-10**] his COPD and rib Fx from compressions. Also clearly
   tiring from respiratory effort. There does not seems to be a diffusion
   defect as he has oxygenated well throughout this hospitalization. Also
   a component of aspiration PNA is complicating and even etiologic to his
   presentation.
   - Extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**].
   - ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had
   initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated.
   - CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion
   which pre-dates his respiratory distress
   - Sputum Cx during intubation growing oropharyngeal flora consistent
   with aspiration PNA
   - Given above concerns for aspiration, started empirically on
   vanc+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
   - Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with PEEP 5 and pressure support of
   10. He seems to be tolerating this well
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, needs NGT vs PO trial today.
   -continue high dose statin on PO access available
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24. This metabolic
   picture is consistent with poor nutrition and generally poor metabolic
   state
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   .

   blue.  Does not appear to be a primary cardiac process.
   - Holding BB given hypotension, bradycardia.

 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in

   - IP [**Name (NI) 1850**], no role for bronch in the acute post MI setting.
   .

   neuropathy v anoxic brain injury or CVA.

   hyperchloremic non-AG acidosis. No ARF or diarrhea, likely in setting
   of aggressive IVF with NS.

   -family discussion

   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   Complex events overnight reviewed in detail with CCU team.
   Change in neuro exam post extubation
   Bradycardia arrest with evidence of high grade AV block with narrow
   compex QRS
   Probable aspiration pneumonia
   Physical Examination
   L sided neglect and flaccid weakness. Also ? R leg weakness. Unable to
   cooperate with sensory exam; No facial weaness.
   Awake and appears alert. He has speech but difficult to hear due to
   weak voice;
   Diffuse lung rhonchi;
   No change in cardiac exam;
   Medical Decision Making
   No evidenc eof recurrent ischemia or heart failure.
   Cause of change in neurologic exam and duration unclear. Of note he had
   similar bradycardia events prior to evidence of inferior STEMI.
   Ischemia not likley primary cause now and late for reperfusion
   arrhythmia.
   Primary respiratory event most likely althoughs ABGs reasonable before
   and after event- > acute aspiration or plugging.
   Primary neurlogic event also a possibility.
   Today airway and respiratory status seem stable on BiPap. Will
   reintubate if any change.
   For head CT today.
   Above discussed extensively with patient.
   Total time spent on patient care: 60 minutes of critical care time.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man who presented to the hospital with inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization. He was initially hypotensive and required dopamine/dobutamine. He was extubated and later became bradycardic and hypotensive, requiring code blue. The patient has a history of poor nutrition and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia. He has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and his ABG shows a pH of 7.27, pCO2 of 52, and pO2 of 76.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure. His ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and his oxygen saturation is 99%.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a history of poor nutrition and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia. His sputum culture is positive for oropharyngeal flora, and his CXR shows a RUL cavitary lesion.
3. Bradycardia: The patient had an episode of bradycardia that required code blue. He is at risk for further bradycardia episodes.
4. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension and is at risk for further hypotensive episodes.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is unstable, and he is at risk for further neurological complications, including anoxic brain injury or CVA.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to aggressive IVF with NS. He is at risk for further metabolic acidosis if his IVF is not adjusted.
7. Poor nutrition: The patient has a history of poor nutrition and is at risk for further malnutrition.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of inferior STEMI and is at risk for further cardiovascular complications, including heart failure or recurrent ischemia.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's bradycardia and adjust his medication as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust his medication as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication as needed.
5. Adjust the patient's IVF to reduce the risk of metabolic acidosis.
6. Continue to provide nutrition support to the patient.
7. Consider referring the patient to a nutritionist for further evaluation and management.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust his medication as needed.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p

   .
   # Hypotension
 Pt s/p inferior STEMI, initially hypotensive requiring
   dopamine/dobutamine. Switched to levo.  Turned off yesterday am, pt
   extubated, later on became bradycardic and hypotensive. Was on levophed
   with labile BPs, now back on dopamine, and IVF for hypotensive.  Ddx
   for this new episode:  Less likely primarily cardiac as no evidence of
   ECG changes, increase in CEs, possibly in setting of vagal episode or
   aspiration.  Also on ddx is primary neurologic process, acute stroke,
   metastatic disease or anoxic brain injury.
   - Dopamine prn and IVF boluses for BP, needs new a-line today.
   - F/u cx, covering broadly with vanc/zosyn for asp pna, needs ID
   approval today, planned 8 day course.  Started evening of [**2-15**].
   - CT followed by MRI to eval above neuro issues, ? neuro c/s.
   .
   # Respiratory failure - intubated in setting of code at OSH.  No known
   h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing one
   exam.  The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] is
   hypoventilating [**2-10**] his COPD and rib Fx from compressions. Also clearly
   tiring from respiratory effort. There does not seems to be a diffusion
   defect as he has oxygenated well throughout this hospitalization. Also
   a component of aspiration PNA is complicating and even etiologic to his
   presentation.
   - Extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**].
   - ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had
   initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated.
   - CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion
   which pre-dates his respiratory distress
   - Sputum Cx during intubation growing oropharyngeal flora consistent
   with aspiration PNA
   - Given above concerns for aspiration, started empirically on
   vanc+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
   - Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with PEEP 5 and pressure support of
   10. He seems to be tolerating this well
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, needs NGT vs PO trial today.
   -continue high dose statin on PO access available
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24. This metabolic
   picture is consistent with poor nutrition and generally poor metabolic
   state
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .

   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   .

   .

 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in

   Pulmonary not planning to bronch during this admission.
   - ruling out for TB, [**3-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm), read as negative
   - negative pressure room, until AFBs read.
   - IP [**Name (NI) 1850**], no role for bronch in the acute post MI setting.
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Pt with ongoing poor orientation and not fully
   communicative. Improved post-extubation. Nevertheless, has ongoing
   flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes. Could be consistent with ICU
   neuropathy v anoxic brain injury or CVA.
   -CT/MRI as above.
   .
   # Acidosis, mixed respiratory and metabolic. Metabolic is
   hyperchloremic non-AG acidosis. No ARF or diarrhea, likely in setting
   of aggressive IVF with NS.
   -Substitute LR for IVF.
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   -family discussion
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, who presented to the emergency department with hypotension and respiratory failure. He was intubated and treated with dopamine and dobutamine for hypotension. He was later extubated and developed bradycardia and hypotension, requiring another code blue. He has been diagnosed with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, with a component of aspiration pneumonia. He also has a right upper lobe cavitary lesion on CT and a liver lesion, which may be related to TB or malignancy. He has altered mental status, with ongoing poor orientation and flaccid limbs, which may be due to ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including aspiration pneumonia, COPD, and rib fractures from compressions. He is at risk for further respiratory failure and may require reintubation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac history includes inferior STEMI and RCA revascularization. He is at risk for cardiac complications, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be due to ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or CVA. He is at risk for further neurological deterioration and may require neuroimaging studies to determine the cause of his altered mental status.
4. Infection: The patient has a right upper lobe cavitary lesion on CT and a liver lesion, which may be related to TB or malignancy. He is at risk for further infection and may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient has a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions and treatments. He is at risk for further metabolic complications, including hyperkalemia, hypokalemia, and hypoglycemia.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of poor nutrition and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including malnutrition, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient has experienced episodes of hypotension and bradycardia, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions and treatments. He is at risk for further hemodynamic instability and may require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide supportive care, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and provide supportive care, including medications to manage heart failure and arrhythmias.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and provide supportive care, including medications to manage seizures and sedation.
4. Continue to evaluate the patient's infection risk and provide appropriate antibiotics and other treatments as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's metabolic status and provide supportive care, including medications to manage acidosis and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Continue to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal status and provide supportive care, including nutrition and hydration therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and provide supportive care, including medications to manage hypotension and bradycardia.

   compressions were given. His recurrent LOCs could be due to these vagal

   - Currently on dopamine  for pressure support as BP was very labile on

   - Concern for aspiration PNA and component of sepsis. Started
   empirically on vanco+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**].
   .

   h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing one
   exam.  The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] is
   hypoventilating [**2-10**] his COPD and rib Fx from compressions. Also clearly
   tiring from respiratory effort. There does not seems to be a diffusion
   defect as he has oxygenated well throughout this hospitalization. Also
   a component of aspiration PNA is complicating and even etiologic to his

   - ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had
   initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated.
   - CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion
   which pre-dates his respiratory distress

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization. He has been experiencing respiratory failure, shock, and altered mental status. The patient's condition has been unstable, with episodes of bradycardia and hypotension, which were treated with atropine and pressors.

The patient's respiratory status has been a concern, with a diagnosis of COPD and clubbing on examination. He was intubated initially, but was successfully extubated. However, his ABG results show a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, which has returned since extubation. The CXR is consistent with aspiration PNA, and the patient has been started on empiric antibiotics.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also a concern, with a diagnosis of cardiogenic shock, which is being treated with dopamine and dobutamine. His coronary arteries are diseased, and he has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL, which has improved with hydration. His metabolic acidosis is also a concern, and he has been treated with fluids and electrolyte replacement.

The patient's mental status has been altered, with poor orientation and flaccid limbs. He has also been experiencing hypothermia, with a temperature of 94.7F on admission.

The patient's blood work has revealed several abnormalities, including a white blood cell count of 13.8 K/uL, a hematocrit of 33.9%, and a platelet count of 310 K/uL. His liver function tests are also abnormal, with a total bilirubin level of 1.4 mg/dL and a alkaline phosphatase level of 130 IU/L.

The patient's prognosis is uncertain, and he requires continued close monitoring and management in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with inferior STEMI, s/p RCA revascularization, and is currently on dopamine for pressure support. He has a history of limited known PMH and is currently experiencing shock/hypotension, respiratory failure, coronary artery disease, and altered mental status.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* T: 36.3C (97.3F)
* HR: 46 bpm
* BP: 102/36 mmHg
* RR: 27 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 13.8
* Hct: 33.9%
* Plt: 310
* Cr: 0.8 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.42
* TCO2: 21 mmHg
* Glucose: 112 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.0 g/dL
* LDH: 339 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.8 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: Elderly man, cachetic, and in distress
* HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI
* Neck: L IJ, JVP 8 cm, difficult to assess respiratory effort
* Cardiac: RR, NL S1S2, no MRG
* Lungs: Decreased BS on the R compared to the L, coarse breath sounds with poor air movement
* Abdomen: Soft, NTND, + BS
* Extremities: No edema, distal pulses present, clubbing
* Neuro: Opens eyes, nods on commands, LEs are flaccid, LUE also flaccid, some purposeful movements of the RUE

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Monitor culture results
* Continue IVF boluses
* Wean pressors today as tolerated
* Continue BiPAP for now with minimal PEEP to prevent worsening hypotension from poor venous return
* Code blue on [**2166-2-15**] at 08:30 PM
* Concern for aspiration PNA and component of sepsis
* Started empirically on vanco+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
* Extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**]
* ABG shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated
* CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion which pre-dates his respiratory distress
* Sputum Cx during intubation growing oropharyngeal flora consistent with aspiration PNA
* Given above concerns for aspiration, started empirically on vanc+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
* Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with PEEP 5 and pressure support of 10
* Seemed to be tolerating this well

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: Given the patient's history of aspiration PNA and component of sepsis, there is a high risk of developing sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require further respiratory support.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he may require further cardiac support.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be a sign of a neurological complication, such as anoxic brain injury or CVA.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he may require further renal support.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment to correct it.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications from occurring or worsening.
